text:
Broadway, east side, north from, but not including, 34th Street. In the centre is the Seventy-First Regiment Armory. In a few years this site will be occupied by the New York Herald Building. About 1885.

New York Edison Company Collection.
Sixth Avenue at 34th Street, looking north on Broadway, James J. Corbett bar in centre. Corbett had recently defeated Sullivan. About 1892. Photographed by International News.

Sixth Avenue & Broadway, at West 34th Street as viewed northward from the Dime Savings Bank on 32nd Street. In the foreground is the triangular plot identified as Gree- ley Square. The "El" station at the left is at 33rd Street. Across the tracks is the continuation of Broadway with the old 71st Inf. Regiment Armory to the right. Partially appearing on the right is the Broadway Tabernacle at 34th Street.

Prior to 1892

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broadway, west side, north from and including 34th Street. The brownstone church in the right foreground is the Broadway Tabernacle. The only buildings shown which are familiar to modern eyes are the New York Herald Building, which is shown in the right centre; the Hotel Normandie, in the centre background, which will be demolished in 1928; and the Metropolitan Opera House, in the left background, which will still stand in 1936, with every prospect of surviving for some years to come. Also shown is the Herald Square Theatre, on the N.W. corner of 35th Street, and the Hotel Marlborough, on the west side between 36th and 37th Streets.

About 1895.

Brown Brothers.

Sixth Avenue and Broadway, north from W. 33rd Street, showing the "El" tracks upon the numerical Avenue. To the right is the diagonal Broadway. 34th Street is where the Broadway Tabernacle appears. The distinctive Herald Building is north of 35th Street, separating Broadway (left) from 6th Avenue. At the left is the southbound platform obstructing the sign that identifies Jim Corbett's Saloon. The latter was a world's heavyweight boxing champion.

1899

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Sixth Avenue and West 34th Street, showing the Broadway Tabernacle Congregational Church, organized in 1840, and building erected in 1859.

About 1900

No record.

Sixth Avenue (left), at the S. W. corner of West 34th Street (right), showing the site of the later Saks Department Store. Note the saloon on the left operated by Jim Corbett, the Worlds heavy weight champion. On the right is Marsh's Restaurant & Cafe.

About 1901

H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broadway at the S.W. corner of 34th Street, showing some of the buildings which are about to be demolished for the erection of the new Saks Department Store, which will later be known as Saks-34th Street.

1901.

Ewing Galloway.

Broadway, west side, north from West 34th Street. The buildings to the left of the center were removed for the Macy Dept. Store. The Herald Square (formerly Park) Theatre is at the N. W. corner of 35th Street. In the block above is the Hotel Marlbro. On the right appears the Metropolitan Opera building.

About 1901

H. N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

1319-1321 Broadway, west side, between 34th and 35th Streets, one of the buildings to be torn down for the erection of the department store of R. H. Macy & Company. 1901.

Ewing Galloway.

Broadway, north across West 34th Street. At the right is the open triangular area, Herald Square, identified with the distinctive Herald Building at it's base. This is formed by the intersection of Broadway and Sixth Avenue.

About 1901

Gift of Urbrock Collection

Broadway and the west side of Sixth Avenue, north from 34th Street. The centre building, fronting on Broadway and Sixth Avenue, was formerly the Seventy-First Regiment Armory, and is now the New York Herald Building. Later, in 1928, it will be cut in half; the narrower, southern half will remain, and in 1936 will house the Rogers Peet Company. The 35th Street half, however, will be demolished and replaced by the 24-story Herald Square Building. In the background is the recently built Times Building, which has caused the name of Longacre Square to be changed to Times Square. About 1905.

(1) Typical noonday street rush at Sixth Ave., and 34th Street, when towering skyscrapers literally belch humanity into the streets. About 1921.

(2) Christmas shoppers at 34th Street and Broadway; one of the World's busiest corners.

December 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Street scenes - Shoppers and crowds

text:
(1) Typical noonday street rush at Sixth Ave., and 34th Street, when towering skyscrapers literally belch humanity into the streets. About 1921.

(2) Christmas shoppers at 34th Street and Broadway; one of the World's busiest corners.

December 24, 1935.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Street scenes - Shoppers and crowds

text:
Broadway at the N.W. corner of 34th Street. Almost the entire picture is taken up by the department store of R. H. Macy & Company; but the corner building itself is not a part of the store. About 1922.

Underwood & Underwood.
Gift of E. M. Jenks.

At the intersection of Broadway and Sixth Ave., at West 34th Street. On the left is Broadway, north from and including West 34th Street. Also shown is Sixth Ave., (Sixth Ave., Elevated) north from, but not including 34th Street. Rogers Peet Building is shown on West 35th Street, north side, from Broadway to Sixth Ave. Macy's Dept., Store is barely discernable on Broadway. (Building with clock) The N. Y. Times Building and the Astor Hotel are shown in the background, at the head of Broadway.

February 7, 1927.

New York Edison Company.

Broadway, west side, from 34th to 38th Streets, showing also 34th Street, north side, west from Broadway. The large building in the centre is Macy's Department Store. Above it is the Johnson Building; the Lefcourt-Marlborough Building, on the site of the old Marlborough Hotel; the Lefcourt-State Building; and the Bricken-Broadway Building, on the site of the old Broadway Theatre. About 1928.

Ewing Galloway.
Subway plan of Herald Square. August, 1928
title: Transportation - Subway.

text:
Sixth Ave., east side, north from but not including 34th Street.
February 5, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

R. H. Macy & Company, one of New York City's largest department stores, Broadway, west side, from 35th to 34th Streets. In the foreground is the former Seventy-First Regiment Armory, half of which has been demolished for the construction of the Herald Square Building.

January 30, 1929.

P. L. Sperr.

Broadway, north from 34th Street. R. H. Macy and Company, a large department store, is shown at the right. Above it, in the distance, is the Metropolitan Opera House, the New York Times Building, and the Hotel Astor.
In the centre, the former Seventy-First Regiment Armory and Herald Building has been cut in half; and the northern half demolished. On the site of the latter has risen the Herald Square Building, which the southern half is occupied by Rogers Peet & Company.
About 1930.

Ewing Galloway.
title: Manhattan: Herald Square - Broadway - 34th Street (North).

text:
1. Herald Square, north from West 34th Street, showing Broadway (left) intersecting Sixth Ave. (right, elevated line thereon). At the apex (West 35th Street) is the 3-story Rogers Peet Building (formerly the New York Herald Building). At the rear of same and occupying the balance of the triangle is the new 24-story Herald Square Building.
September 29, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

2. Broadway & 6th Ave. Neg. A-243 July 18, 1941
P.L. Sperr

3. Broadway from below 33rd St. Neg. A-120 July 18, 1941
P.L. Sperr

General View Midtown Manhattan, West 40's and 50's: View 1 is northwestward across the area lying between Sixth Avenue and Broadway and between 42nd and 49th street. In the lower left corner is the roof of the Hippodrome and the Sixth Avenue "El". The Hotel Astor is on the upper left hand corner.

View 2 is northwestward across the West 50's seen from Radio City. In the upper right hand corner are luxurious residential hotels on Central Park South.

P. L. Sperr

View 1: June 24, 1931
View 2: December 1, 1932
title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - West 40s and 50s.

View 2 is northwestward across the West 50's seen from Radio City. In the upper right hand corner are luxurious residential hotels on Central Park South.

title: General view - Midtown Manhattan - West 40s and 50s.

text:
Macy's Thanksgiving Parade, 1932, No. 18. Releasing the balloons at Macy's Store, 34th Street at Broadway, seen from and including Seventh Avenue.
At the end of the parade, at Herald Square, the balloons are released and allowed to rise and blow away. A cash prize is offered to the lucky boy or girl who can find one of these balloons and bring it back to Macy's the next day.
Here goes the jaguar. The alligator and the bear are seen in the street below. These pictures incidentally give a splendid view of the Empire State Building, the tallest in the world.
November 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
No. 19. The dachshund follows.
November 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
No. 20. The pig rises in the air. The alligator is still waiting below; and the jaguar can still be discerned, up in the air above the Empire State Building.
November 24, 1932.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Macy's Thanksgiving Parade.

text:
Herald Square, Manhattan

Federal Art Project
"Changing New York"
Berenice Abbott, photographer

Code III B-1
July 16, 1936

p. 130, Changing New York
title: Manhattan: Herald Square - 34th Street (West).

text:
West 34th Street, east from Sixth Avenue, showing prominently pavement conditions after the removal of the former streetcar tracks by the W. P. A. At the right margin is the Hotel McAlpin. Beyond, at Fifth Avenue, is the base of the towering Empire State Building. To the left of the latter is McCreery's and Altman's stores.

February 7, 1937

W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project

West 34th Street, west from Broadway, showing pavement conditions after the removal of the former crosstown street cars and their necessary tracks. The latter were eliminated through the assistance of the W.P.A. Note the new bus service on the left. At the right is Macy's Department Store extending westward to Eighth Ave.
February 7, 1937
W. P. A., photo
Five Boroughs Project

(1)
East 34th Street, from east River showing 6th Avenue Bus and W.F.A. Re-Construction Works.

April 26, 1937.

(2)
West 34th Street, looking Eastwards across ninth Avenue The Tower of the Empire State Building at Fifth Avenue, shows in the background.

April 17, 1941.

P.L. Sperr/

(1)
Seventh Avenue west side and 42nd Street, looking south Stanley None house showin adjoining southwest
corner 42nd Street.
September 1933.

(2)
Herald Square, at intersection of Broadway and Sixth Avenue looking northward before demolition of 6th
Avenue, "L".
George L.Balgur
February 7, 1937.

(1)
6th Avenue, south from W. 34th Street, showing the "El" structure and its 33rd Street Station. This was mainly patronized by shoppers to Gimbels, Sak's and Macys. The first two of these enterprises appear here occupying the 34th - 33rd and 33rd-32nd Street frontages. Note the interstore bridge connecting these.
Views 2 and 3 show the absence of the "El" and the station remaining. This will remain for about a month and then join the balance of this structure. Underground, at this date, the 6th Avenue Subway is under construction. At the left is Broadway, which intersects with 6th Avenue and leaves two triangular parks; the southerly of which (Greeley Square) appears partially here.
Views 1,2 and 3:April 5, 1939.
P.L.Sperr

(1)

Sixth Avenue and Broadway, north from West 34th Street, showing the subway construction shaft occupying the former park site that was identified as Herald Square. This received its name from the newspaper plant above. One-half of this site still contains the low original building, the remainder being improved with the towering Herald Square Building.

Broadway is on the left and 6th Avenue on the right. The former thoroughfare is the vantage point for the photographer in view 2 and from which he is viewing north-eastward towards the office building at the N. E. corner of 6th Avenue and W. 35th Street.

View 1: March 29, 1939
View 2: February 18, 1939

P. L. Sperr

text:
Herald Square: The William Earl Dodge statue prior to removal to Bryant Park. This is to be replaced with Minerva and the Bell Ringers that previously were mounted on the former Herald Building. View 2 shows this feature under construction.

1: July 8, 1940
2: Sept. 27, 1940

George D. Chinn

P. L. Sperr
